 FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA PRIVATE FARMER SUPPORT PROJECT Credit and Project Summary Borrower: The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia Executing Agency: Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy Beneficiaries: Private farmers Amount: SDR: 5.4 million (US$7.9 million equivalent) Terms: Standard IDA terms: Thirty-five years, including ten years of grace Objectives: The project is designed to support the economic transformation process by strengthening agricultural support services to private farmers in order to increase their productivity and income. Description: The project would fund technical specialists, training and equipment that would be used to: (i) develop participatory and accountable extension services through cost-sharing with farmer organizations and reorientation of government extension; (ii) carry out on-farm adaptive research; (iii) privatize the veterinary service and enhance government's epidemiology and border quarantine capabilities; and (iv) establish a market news service and design a horticulture wholesale market system. The project will also support the institutional development of financial institutions involved in rural finance, including of Participating Financial Institutions (PFIs) under the Private Sector Development Project (PSDP). Benefits: Private farmers will be the principal beneficiaries, deriving benefits from improved support services. Agricultural research and extension is expected to lead to reduced production costs and increased farm incomes. For example, adapting known technology to Macedonian conditions can reasonably be expected to enable a 15% to 30% reduction in herbicide usage worth as much as US$1 million per year. Farm models suggest that more effective advice on production technology, market information, animal health services and credit can boost small, private farmers incomes by 10 to over 50 percent. Better enzootic disease control and livestock product sanitary inspection will enhance consumer safety as well help insure continued access to European Union markets. Pilot Initiatives to shift some of the costs of Government services, for example, advisory services to the beneficiaries will establish a basis on which to reduce public expenditures in the range of US$0.7 to 1.4 million per year. Project benefits will be supported and enhanced by the PSDP project that is being processed in parallel and which will facilitate farmers' access to credit.
 - ii - Risks: The principal risks are economic and geo-political. Economic risks stem from the possibility of macroeconomic destabilization and delays in structural reforms. However, the Government continues to adhere to its reform program and contemplates new reform measures including the privatization of agri-kombinats and further reforms of agricultural price and trade policy. The reopening of the country's southern border, and more recently the ending of the Serbian embargo, should help in stimulating trade and private sector development. The reforms supported by the FESAC, together with on-going dialogue with the IMF (to extend the Stand-by Arrangement) and the Bank Group on a proposed SAL should minimize the risk of policy slippage. Geo- political risks stemming from regional conflicts and ethnic strife in the Balkan region remain an overhanging risk for any operation of this kind. Project specific risks relate mainly to potential resistance at the operational level by various public institutions and services involved in the project to give up traditional influence and responsibilities. This would be mitigated by an intensive retraining program and seminars explaining the rationale for the changes introduced under the project. These are being addressed through technical specialists already provided by a PPF for start-up activities, and by early project implementation features. Finally, cost-sharing arrangements in the provision of advisory services to farmers may encounter poor receptivity due to past experience with Government. This risk will be mitigated by developing strong incentives for community participation. The proposed mid- term review will provide an opportunity to review and change project design if required. INTRODUCTION 1.01 The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is a landlocked country on the Balkan Peninsula with a population of about 2 million people and an area of 25,700 km2. With 45% of the population rurally based, agrarian linkages are strong and help shape the national character. Agricultural production accounts for about 15% of employment. Though constrained by normal variations in weather, marketing problems, and the difficult political environment, agriculture has an important place in the national economy and was the only sector to grow in 1994. 1.02 The proposed Private Farmer Support Project (PFSP) was identified in September 1993 following a February 1993 joint agriculture review mission of IDA and the FAO Investment Center. In February and May 1994, FAO Investment Center assisted the Government with project preparation. Following an IDA mission in July 1994, project preparation continued through a Project Preparation Facility (PPF). Following appraisal in April 1995, a Deutsche Marks (DM) 4 million farm credit component was included in the Private Sector Development Project (DM 18 million general line of credit, which is being processed in parallel). The PSDP would be an important source of investment credit for private farmers interested in expanding operations and improving their productivity. II. SECTORAL CONTEXT A. The Economy in Transformation 2.01 Macroeconomic Adjustment. The Government has made encouraging progress in macroeconomic adjustment and structural reforms. In 1994, the Government implemented a set of comprehensive reform measures including strict budgetary discipline and monetary reforms which brought greater price stability. Significant progress has been made in normalizing the external debt situation, enacting basic laws to restructure and privatize the inefficient, socially-owned enterprise and financial sectors, and in reforming the social safety net. Most foreign trade barriers have been removed. Tariffs are low, averaging 10% with a large number of zero-rated items. Restrictions that remain apply mainly to metal and a limited number of agricultural products. A source of price distortion in agriculture are variable levies mainly for wheat, milk and sugar. Economic reforms planned for 1996 seek to accelerate the process of financial stabilization and to enhance structural reforms in the enterprise, banking, and social sectors. The Bank Group intends to support further deepening of the reform process through a Structural Adjustment Loan (SAL) currently under preparation which would address the distortions in the agricultural sector. 2.02 Macroeconomic Trends. The decline in overall output since 1990 has yet to be reversed, although the agricultural sector showed nearly 8% growth in 1994. Registered unemployment has increased to about 20%. On the other hand, inflation, at a monthly peak of 80% in early 1992, declined during implementation of the second stabilization program to 2% a month by March 1994. For 1995, the annual rate of inflation is estimated at about 8%. Fiscal management, however, has been a problem. Growing government expenditures increased fiscal deficits from 3.4% of Gross Social Product (GSP) in
 -2 - 1991 to 11.1 % in 1993. Improved government efforts to raise revenues have resulted in a decline of the fiscal deficit to about 2.4% in 1994. Traditional export markets in the former Yugoslavia and the Council of Mutual Economic Assistance were lost, and trade further suffered because of the Greek blockade. Nevertheless, overall exports to non-traditional markets have increased and appear to have compensated for the loss of traditional markets. The composition of exports has also changed and is characterized by a decline in manufactured exports while agricultural exports have risen in relative importance. The prospects for peace in the Region and the lifting of the Greek blockade have significantly improved the prospects of economic recovery, in which the agricultural sector will play a vital role. B. The Agricultural Sector 2.03 The Resource Base. The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia covers 2.57 million ha, of which about 50% is agricultural land including 662,000 ha of arable land and 640,000 ha of permanent pasture (principally in mountainous areas); forests cover a further 950,000 ha. The irrigation command area is 120,000 ha. Irrigated farming presently is restricted to about 50,000 ha because of insufficient water and breakdown of irrigation infrastructure. Although only modestly endowed with natural resources, the country has areas conducive to the production of a wide variety of crops, including cereals, forages, industrial crops and off-season fruit and vegetables. The extensive pasture resources support traditional sheep farming, a basis for a profitable lamb export business. 2.04 The Importance of Agriculture. In contrast to other sectors, agriculture production has always been predominantly a private sector activity in the country. The sector's contribution to GSP possibly understates its importance to the economy, in that 45% of the population lives in rural areas, and their welfare and incomes are closely linked to agriculture. Farming is expected to assume an increasingly important role in the medium-term as labor is shed from the industrial sector. In 1994, GSP per worker in agriculture was estimated at 127% of the country's average in all sectors of the economy. 2.05 The majority of urban population retains close family links with the agricultural sector. Most farm families live in close-knit village communities. Women play an important role in agricultural management and production on private farms as members and administrators of agri-kombinats (AKs) as well as in governmental services (e.g., extension or veterinary). Education levels of farm families are lower than those of urban counterparts. While there are wide variations, farm families are commonly seen as risk-averse and conservative. On the other hand, small private farmers have been most agile in responding to the changing market circumstances associated with the transformation process. Most farm families have assured food supplies and substantial homes (albeit, sometimes, without running water in the more remote areas), and are reasonably well mechanized, averaging one tractor per 9.7 ha. Ninety- three percent of the country's estimated 51,000 tractors are owned by private farmers. 2.06 Agricultural trade constituted about 16% of export earnings -- about US$172 million in 1994, a sharp decline from 1992 and 1993 levels, when agriculture exports were US$323 million and US$389 million respectively. Food and live animals exports were US$110 million - about 10% of all exports compared to US$184 million in 1992. Major exports in 1994 were fruit and vegetables (US$70 million), wine (US$15 million), and meat (US$8 million). However, current trade data should be taken with caution. In the past, the country was an important supplier of fruit and vegetables, and lamb and (to a lesser extent) beef to Greece, Italy, and the other Republics of Yugoslavia. The decline in exports is primarily related to the Greek blockade and UN sanctions on Serbia, but also to the transformation process in which hard budget constraints on agri-kombinats disrupted the old marketing channels. The
 - 3 - restructuring of the country's financial system, the lack of export financing, and problems securing working capital (a particular problem for agriculture given the seasonality of the agricultural production cycle) also present formidable barriers for exporters. The greatest losses in exports have occurred in live animal and meat exports. High-value vegetable and fruit producers also face an increasingly competitive market because of higher marketing (transportation) costs and, more recently, appreciation of the Denar. 2.07 The Private Farming Sector in the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is made up of small farms. About 70% of arable land, approximately 458,000 ha, belongs to private farmers, consisting of some 177,000 families owning an average 2.6 ha of land. All agricultural land is fragmented, although the actual extent of this is not known precisely. Private farms are often highly diversified and grow a comparatively large number of crops. This is partly due to traditions by which families ensure self- sufficiency, spread labor requirements, and avert risk. There are notable variations in this pattern, for example, where farmers specialize in vegetables and/or fruit production and, occasionally, in livestock fattening and dairying. 2.08 Farms are operated almost exclusively by labor of the extended family, although casual labor may be employed during peak demand periods (particularly with vegetable production). Where male family members are employed by the neighboring agri-kombinat or at a local industry, women are often the primary managers of the family's home-based livestock and vegetable/fruit production units. While the farming systems are, for the most part, relatively labor intensive, the early to mid-1980s were a period of over-mechanization for many private farms -- the result of an extended period of subsidized credit, subsidized farm machinery, and the promotion of mechanization as a "modern" farming practice. 2.09 Farm family incomes, for which little data is available, are derived from both cash and non-cash as well as from farm and non-farm sources. Cash income arises from three main sources -- the sale of farm products, cash remittances, and other off-farm earnings. Off-farm social sector earnings have been important income sources in the past, though they are now reduced substantially due to social sector layoffs. Pensions, for which all Macedonians are eligible, represent a vital, and reportedly reasonably good safety net for aged private farmers. Farmers report that annual pensions range from US$500 to US$1,000 equivalent. 2.10 Agri-kombinats farm about 200,000 ha of farm land, and account for about 25% of primary production and for 60% of processing and marketing services. There are 217 agri-kombinats with an average land holding size of 950 ha. The range extends from small intensive enterprises to extensive farms -- the largest, the Pelagonija Kombinat at Bitola--covers 25,000 ha. AKs are typically organized into vertically-integrated production and agro-processing complexes engaged in a wide range of activities including input supply, farming, out-grower production contracts, primary production processing, and commodity retailing and trading. While they continue to exert strong influence in the agricultural sector, their long-term economic survival is in doubt. This has been confirmed by detailed analysis of three of the largest AKs during preparation of the Financial and Enterprise Sector Adjustment Credit (FESAC) which revealed major technical and financial problems. Under the Special Restructuring Program of the FESAC, three of the largest AKs were put into receivership and would be broken up and privatized. The proposed SAL would support the continuation of privatization of the agri-kombinats. 2.11 The input supply system is being augmented by private trading companies moving into the input supply market which government policy encourages. As the importance of AKs declined, and given the relative ease of entry for new business, small private businesses have developed and become important in the new upstream and downstream agricultural service sectors. Indeed, competition is appearing in
 the supply of services to the private farm sector which was not the case before independence. The demise of AKs is not expected to constrain growth by private farmers. International agro-businesses are largely absent from the market. In this area the process of transformation is being retarded by the lack of private-sector investment (in part due to the unavailability of credit for working capital and investment), and the general uncertainties associated with the Region. New investment is needed in private agro- business supplying tractors and equipment, seed and fertilizer, and custom services for specialized equipment. 2.12 Although decreasing, agricultural marketing continues to be dominated by the agri-kombinats. Overall this inhibits competition and limits alternatives available to farmers. This situation is likely to persist until completion of the privatization of AKs. No commodity exchange exists, nor is this likely to be viable until commodity grading improves and production and organization uncertainties are reduced. Farmers' market access is provided through informal local green markets and sale to social sector enterprises -- usually under forward contract and, on a limited but rapidly increasing scale, to private traders. For high-value products for exports, such as off-season vegetables and fruit, there is an immediate need to develop a wholesale system to replace the agri-kombinats and provide a wholesale service to the many small vegetable producers and new, private traders. 2.13 There is no formal market research or information service, an activity which in the past had been provided by federal services of the former Yugoslavia. Near-real-time market information is needed on prices, volumes, and qualities of product moving through domestic and international markets. Informed analyses of market trends, opportunities, and outlooks are not readily available. Informal, casual sources that are currently available usually lack perspective and breadth and are hardly sufficient to form cropping pattern or investment choices. 2.14 Agricultural subsidies have declined from 23 % of agricultural GSP in 1993 to an estimated 6%, or about US$50 million, in 1995. However, they still represent almost 90% of Government's agricultural budget and primarily benefit agri-kombinats. About US$24 million is for price subsidies, US$7 million for seed subsidies, and US$19 million for credit subsidies (mainly for storage). In 1994, wheat accounted for 53% of the total subsidies, tobacco for 22%, and milk for 1 1%. While low by Western European standards, subsidies represent an inefficient use of resources with little economic or equity rationale. Government intends to continue phasing out subsidies, one of the policy issues to be addressed under the proposed SAL. 2.15 The Government attempts to manage agricultural foreign trade by tariffs, special import levies and quotas on imports and exports. Tariffs are generally low and most quotas do not have substantial effect. The most distortive instrument are special levies on the imports of wheat, milk and sugar. Recent analysis supported by USAID indicates high nominal protection coefficients for wheat - 2.18, raw sugar - 1.66, refined sugar - 1.37 and cow milk - 1.77, primarily because of the special levies. Changes in these policies are important for overall efficiency reasons and for access to the World Trade Organization. The proposed SAL would also address this issue. C. The Institutional Framework 2.16 The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy employing about 420 staff with fewer than 20% headquarters-based, is the central organization with administrative responsibility for agricu!ture, rural development, natural resource management (forestry and fisheries), and the protection
 of flora and fauna. Formally, MAFWE consists of three Departments 'Agriculture, Forestry, and Administration and Legal Affairs' and three Republic Agencies 'Water Economy, Veterinary, and Agriculture and Forestry Inspectorate (Annex 1).' Since national independence, and due to the change in financing arrangements, the Macedonian Extension Service (MES) is also part of MAFWE. There is little difference between Departments and Republic Agencies. The latter have as their prime roles regulatory and inspection functions. Inspectorate staff are posted to MAFWE branch offices covering one or more opstinas (municipality) while the small professional staff at the head office is concerned with policy, legislation, and quality control. 2.17 Agricultural Research comprises six research institutes varying in size from a staff of 18 (Kocani) to 144 (Skopje), and the Faculty of Agriculture, University of Cyril and Methodius, Skopje. The research establishment employs 540 staff including 216 professionals, 72% with postgraduate degrees. Overall, the system represents institutional resources left in place following the breakup of the former Yugoslavia and is larger than the country can sustain and afford. Over the medium-term, a "strategic plan" is needed for restructuring the research establishment. 2.18 The Ministry or Science (MOS) is responsible for all research. Agricultural research funding is often allocated to tasks having scientific merit but little relevance to problems and constraints at the farm level. MAFWE does not participate in agricultural research planning or funding. Some applied research funded by AKs has nearly ceased. MOS-supported research was primarily for short-term (usually three-year) projects. MOS also funded some staff at key institutes. Today the bulk of funds needed to maintain research staff and stations is generated by production activities at the institutes. The system is not equipped to meet the needs of private farmers in the changing economic environment. Particularty important is applied research to address the issues concerning soil fertility, e.g., developing economic response curves for various levels of fertilizer use, pasture/meadow management, integrated pest management ([PM), conservation tillage, farm management economics of the major cropping patterns, and the introduction of horticultural varieties with good export potential. 2.19 The Macedonian Extension Service (MES) was first established in 1975 to promote private agriculture, often in close association with agri-kombinat out-grower programs. MES now comprises about 140 professionals in some 30 opstina extension centers. Under the former Yugoslav Republic, MES centers were autonomous, self-managed entities in which the local government shared half the cost with the Republic's Government. Since national independence, MES is funded from the national budget. Most extension staff are technically well qualified. Because of the past practice of associating extension initiatives with various forms of subsidies, e.g., free or highly-subsidized breeding stock, and given the current tight budget situation, MES today reaches a comparatively small number of farmers. Another legacy of the previous system is the heavy production and commodity orientation of the old MES. Consequently, while staff may have an adequate level of technical proficiency, there is little expertise in farm management and participatory methods of working with farmers. Staff also have limited transport, equipment, and operating funds. 2.20 The main constraints, recognized by MAFWE, in the current extension system include: (i) the lack of client accountability; (ii) the lack of effective applied research; (iii) inadequate attention to production economics and farm management; (iv) insufficient knowledge of farmers' resources and difficulties; and (v) inadequate operational budget.

Field veterinary services are provided principally through a network of 27 socially-owned, veterinary stations (clinics or surgeries) established in most opstinas. Stations employ between one and eight veterinarians depending on opstina size and animal population. Veterinary stations generally are well organized and staffed. They are supported with some income derived from drug sales and contracted government services and are supervised by the Macedonian Veterinary Management Unit in the MAFWE. The legislative base for their privatization is anticipated in 1996. All vaccines and most drugs are imported. Laboratory services are provided by the Veterinary Institute in Skopje which, through user charges, is largely self-financing. Overall, the Veterinary Institute offers a comprehensive service to the livestock and livestock product processing industries. 2.22 Farmers' Organizations. Since 1990, some 300 agricultural associations have been formed, although many are inoperative and the status of others is unclear. While these organizations were established under the cooperative law, this law is not consistent with cooperative membership, based on shared unity of interest. Although deemed to be private sector enterprises, their legal status is unclear, and, on the surface, they seem to be made up of kombinat members -- with their leadership drawn from the old management. MAFWE is planning legal changes to clarify, and provide for, regulation of associations. There is a network of 19 commodity-based Sections within the Association of Agriculture and Food Industries of the Chamber of Commerce. Agricultural Sections, which are based regionally and include both farmer and agri-kombinat representation, focused on the major agricultural products of their regions, Kombinat membership has been compulsory, with the kombinats providing the financing. There is no registration of farmer "members," nor are they assessed dues. Consequently, private farmers have had little influence on the AAFI. With the transformation process and the privatization of the agri- kombinats continuing, the role of the AAFI is likely to fade. 2.23 Several technical assistance programs have been completed or are underway to support reform in agriculture. The German Government supports the irrigation sub-sector and is preparing a credit program directed for the re-settlement of German-based refugees. The Netherlands Government is expected to provide bilateral assistance to agriculture. The International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) is preparing a regional development project that focuses on remote, resource poor areas. The Macedonian Center for International Cooperation, an NGO apex organization, is assisting villages in remote locations with infrastructure development and communications packages on a cost- sharing basis with support form the Dutch Reform Church. 2.24 USAID has by far the largest program -- about $10 million in grant funds and bilateral programs -- directly related to the proposed project. Close cooperation has developed during project preparation among IDA, USAID staff and local counterparts. USAID program includes: (i) the establishment of a Business Resource Center to assist entrepreneurs to put together business plans, develop privatization plans and prepare loan applications; (ii) analysis of agricultural price and trade policies; (iii) a number of veterinarian volunteers through Volunteers in Overseas Cooperative Assistance specifically aimed to help privatize veterinarian services; (iv) dairy improvement project to help private dairy farmers increase the production and improve milk quality; (vi) a study of land ownership issues to identify policy options available to Government, particularly with respect to denationalization of land; (vii) finalization and analysis of the 1994 census concerning agriculture; and (viii) a pilot supporting establishment of 20 rural, member-owned, Savings Associations (SAs).

Agriculture and the Environment 2.25 Environmental regulation is the responsibility of the Ministry of Urbanism, Construction and Environmental Protection, as lead Ministry together with MAFWE, the Ministry of Health, and the Institute of Natural Rarities. Laws governing environmental management include the Law on Environment, the Water Law, and the Law for the Protection and Use of Agricultural Land. Environmental issues relating to agriculture primarily include aspects of water quality and use, land degradation, agro-chemical use, and agri-kombinat waste discharge. These issues have economic relevance as they may affect access to Western markets (particularly for environmentally-clean products). Legislation, now in draft form, also would address a wider range of environmental issues and better empower Government to regulate the environment. Land degradation could remain an issue as farmers, under current economic policies, seek to increase profitable small ruminant production in upland areas. However, the policy reforms proposed under the SAL would reduce the current attractiveness of small ruminants in the less productive, more fragile upland areas. Pending development of a national water development policy, water management would remain an area of concern. With IDA assistance, a National Environmental Action Plan is currently under preparation and is expected to be finished in the Spring of 1996. E. Rural Financial Services 2.26 Village-based savings societies date back to the last century. Money lenders and other informal systems of mobilizing savings and extending credit also existed. These systems disappeared during the four decades of state monopoly on banking. With respect to the formal banking sector, the Stopanska Bank, the bank responsible for all agricultural lending in the past, is currently undergoing restructuring and privatization. While there are substantial savings in rural and farm communities, savers have developed distrust of the formal banking system, and, formal financial service for small farmers, rural residents, and holders of remittances have yet to emerge. 2.27 Private farmers have difficulty in accessing the formal, commercial banking system to obtain credit: Loans are typically small and the risks associated with farming are perceived to be high. Compounding the problem are court practices, as well as the underlying legal framework, that are biased against lenders, particularly when on occasion collateral has to be enforced. Chattel mortgages and production inputs are not used. Furthermore the newly privatized commercial banks need to develop their overall asset/liabilities management, risk management and appraisal capabilities, and have few branches in rural areas. Effective demand for credit from private farmers during transition is expected to be modest. This is because small private farmers are wary of debt, particularly when banks commonly ask for two to three times the value of a loan to be backed by land as collateral. Moreover, effective real rates of interest remain high. Most private farmers rely on self-financing. It is expected that these conditions would improve as the ongoing stabilization program progresses. F. World Bank Group Strategy and Rationale for Involvement 2.28 The Government is committed to completing the process of transition to a market economy. The reform agenda is comprehensive and includes: (i) macroeconomic policies to stabilize the economy; (ii) enhancing private sector development through privatization and complementary measures to improve the business environment by reducing the role of the state; (iii) reforming the banking sector; (iv) building on private sector capabilities to increase agricultural production; (v) modernizing the country's physical infrastructure; (vi) developing an effective social safety net; (vii) improving public administration; and
 (viii) improving environmental management. In agriculture, the Government has substantially reduced subsidies and introduced legislation to Parliament to denationalize land and privatize the agri-kombinats. 2.29 The Government strategy has been supported by the Bank Group through policy dialogue and lending program. The Bank Group's Country Assistance Strategy, (Report No. 14379-MK, dated April 19, 1995), which was presented to the Board on May 16, 1995, aims to: (i) facilitate and support the structural reform and the transformation to a market economy; (ii) contribute to financing balance-of- payments requirements; (iii) support structural adjustment and development efforts; and (iv) help to mobilize resources from both official and private sources. The proposed project was identified in the CAS and fully supports the Bank Group's overall strategy for the country, which recognizes that agriculture has significant growth potential and that strengthening private sector capability is key to realizing that potential. 2.30 The initial support to the Government's reform program was provided through the Economic Recovery Project of US$80 million, which has by now been fully implemented. The centerpiece of the Bank Group's current operations is the Financial and Enterprise Sector Adjustment Credit (FY95), which supports the following measures: (i) comprehensive reform of the banking sector and financial markets; (ii) isolation of largest loss-making enterprises from bank credit and leading to liquidation or privatization of major loss makers; (iii) comprehensive privatization program; (iv) special restructuring program for social safety net program. Three of the 25 large loss-making enterprises targeted are in the agricultural sector. 2.31 The Bank Group's strategy for the agriculture sector also reflects the country specific experience gained since the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia joined the Bank Group. As the Country Assistance Strategy points out, the Bank Group's overall strategy in agriculture would promote the reduction of subsidies, privatization of the agri-kombinats, shifting more responsibility for support services to the private sector, and supporting the transformation to a market-lead economy. Under the proposed SAL. The Government has confirmed its agreement in principle to proceed with reforms specifically with respect to liberalizing the trade regime, reforming agricultural price policy and privatizing the agri-kombinats. The Bank Group is also preparing an irrigation project and an agricultural inputs guarantee operation is under consideration. 2.32 As noted above, the proposed project is fully consistent with the Bank Group's Country Assistance Strategy. The proposed project would support the economic transformation process by strengthening the provision of technology and information related services to private farmers, thereby improving their production and income. The project would change mechanisms for provision of technical services to private farmers and initiate important changes in the public institutions providing such services. 3.02 Project Justification. Sustained growth in agriculture is feasible and crucial to overall economic growth. Traditional Macedonian export products such as fruit, vegetables and lamb present viable source of income for private farmers. The proposed project would improve their access to extension services, relevant research, credit and animal health. It would support a reduced and better focused public sector role in agriculture through assistance to the privatization of veterinary services and cost sharing with farmers for their advisory services. It would support exports through market information services and improved animal health control. While growth would be private sector led, the public sector would continue to play a role, albeit redefined, in the provision of agricultural research, advisory services and market information. The project seeks to rationalize and enhance these functions. 3.03 Design considerations. Sustainability of agricultural support services was a major concern in preparing this project. Budgetary resources for public sector expenditures are scarce and this is not expected to change in the near future. The project would support the privatization of the veterinary services and cost-sharing arrangements with farmers for advisory services. The market news services, after establishing credibility and reliability, would be sold to media organizations for commercial publication, thus offsetting the costs of the service to Government. In the longer term, this service is expected to be privatized. As a result, the project is expected to reduce public expenditures in the agricultural sector. The project would also help strengthen the accountability and responsiveness of agricultural support services to farmers. Privatizing veterinary services and shifting some responsibility for provision of advisory services to farmers gives farmers ownership and enhances the accountability between them and agricultural advisors. The project was designed with strong participation by the principal beneficiaries, specifically private farmers, veterinarians and extension agents. B. Project Benefits 5.01 Quantifying the incremental benefits of this sort of project is problematic given the institutional development nature of project activities and numerous non-service factors influencing decision-making at the farm level. Nevertheless, as approximation, indicative financial and economic farm models were analyzed during project preparation to assess the likely impact of project activities at the farm level. Farm modeling of typical private farms in dairy, vegetables, apples and field crops suggest economic rates of return ranging from 15% to over 50% could be obtained from modest, new technological packages that would flow from applied research, better advisory services, better animal husbandry and new investment. 5.02 The proposed project as a whole would have two main benefits. First, private farmers would receive better support from the various public and private services, which would increase their production and incomes. Second, this project would pilot initiatives, for example, in advisory and veterinary services that would establish an experience base to gradually replace obsolete public support services with private services, thus enabling a reduction in the amount of government funding that is being provided to the sector for these kind of services. The project is fully consistent with the Country Assistance Strategy which has identified agriculture as one of the main sectors with promising growth potential. 5.03 Private farmers would be the principal beneficiaries, deriving advantage from more effective support and advice on production technology, marketing information, animal health services and credit. The farm models cited above suggest that the family incomes from new innovations including financing, could result in increases in annual family incomes, using 1994 prices, of US$370 for a 2 ha crop farm in the Bitola region, US$2,400 for a 1/2 ha. intensive vegetable grower in the Strumica area, US$5,600 for a I ha Resin apple grower that replaces his/her current variety and US$6,600 for a 4 cow dairy farmer, or increases from 10 to over 50%. 5.04 A principal benefit from upgrading the animal quarantine services and improving the epidemiological capacity would be to assist in maintaining access for Macedonian livestock products to the EU market. In 1994 that market was worth about US$1 10 million. Two years earlier, because of a breakdown in border control, large numbers of infected dairy/beef cattle were shipping into and through
 - 23 - the country. This resulted in Macedonian livestock products being denied access to EU markets for one year, as well as requiring a large, expensive eradication program. The modest, US$1.1 million project investment in this component, would pay for itself many times over if it only avoided one year of lost international markets. 5.05 Ex-post analysis of agricultural research typically comes up with high returns to investments in research. However, ex-ante, it is problematic to predict which research and when the research will produce the technological innovation(s) which would produce those typical high returns. Nevertheless, we can estimate, for illustrative purposes, some returns that can be reasonably be expected to flow from the kind of applied research envisioned for the project. For example, one of the priority research areas is IPM. Currently about US$3 million (retail) of herbicides (2,4-D, Trifluralin, etc.,) are used on about 100,000 ha of cereals and 10,000 ha of vegetables. It is expected that applied research should be able to adopt new IPM technology to Macedonian conditions whereby at least a 30 percent savings in herbicide use per ha could be realized. Still, if only a fifteen percent savings are realized, it would save cereal and vegetable farmers using herbicides something on the order of US$450,000 annually in production costs on the same area. This of course would also reduce the potential for residual groundwater contamination but no value is estimated for this benefit, though it is significant. 5.06 Similarly, conservation tillage, another priority area for research, offers promising returns. Typically these new tillage practices can increase the effective amount of moisture available to a crop by 20 - 30 percent through increased infiltration (through less runoff) and reduced evaporation. This in turn should easily enable a 10 percent increase in cereal yields, although in drought years this would be even higher. In 1994, a dry year, if average wheat yields were 10 percent greater on half of the cultivated wheat area, i.e., about 58,000 ha, that would have increased wheat production by about 13,000 tons; at US$130 per ton, that would be worth about US$1.7 million. So, while returns to research can not be fully assured, the two examples above suggest that even with modest assumptions as to the value of technological innovations, the returns to investments in agricultural research promise to be substantial. 5.07 Greater involvement of farmers in the provision of support services in which they share ownership and cost with Government would improve the quality and increase service coverage and better respond to their needs. MAFWE and MES staff would become better motivated and more accountable to farmers and be better able to meet the demands of the emerging commercial, family farms. Currently, a typical MES opstina level office, including a director, three high level staff and two technicians costs about US$52,000 per year to run, with about US$40,000 accounted for by salaries. If a farmer organization would take over this function, which is possible, the maximum obligation on the MES would be US$8,000 in the first year, and US$6,000 thereafter offering a potential savings to the Government of US$46,000 per year. Success with this pilot and expansion of this model to 30 opstinas implies that the savings to Government per annum would be on the order of US$1.4 million in 1996 dollars. However, this project does not suggest total phasing out of MES services in that there is an important, although redefined role for public support for advisory services. If even half, or US$0.7 million, could be saved per year, the payback time on this component (US$3.32 million) would be five years. 5.08 SOM would become more efficient in providing market information which would enable farmers, traders and agro-businesses to respond more effectively to market opportunities. The value of timely, accurate market information is difficult to estimate, although it is generally agreed that this is essential for a market economy to work efficiently. (The investment costs for this component is US$0.7 million.) These services are intended to be sold as they become standard, accepted and producers, traders and processors learn to depend on them. In the longer-run, it is expected that this service would become a
 - 24 - private sector business. The rural financial services component would provide short-run assistance (US$0.4 million) to those private farmers that may want to obtain short or medium-term credit during the first two years of the project. With a 15% return on investment, we could expect that this would return to those private farmers who take advantage of this credit at least an addition $500,000 of income in the first two years of the project. More importantly, however, is the building up a client base for the newly commercialized banks in the agricultural sector, something that would not happen in the absence of this project given the lack of experience the PFIs have had with private farmers and their general reluctance to lend to the sector in the first place. Poverty Impact 5.09 The impact of project activities on poverty reduction in rural areas would be largely indirect. Poor farmers are located mainly in remote, mountain areas with poor access and only marginal agricultural potential. In general, private farmers have a more secure economic base than families dependent on employment in industry. About half of the farmers derive their income from full-time farm work; the other half supplements farm income with off-farm employment. The project is classified as a "Not in the Program of Targeted Interventions." B. Project Risks 5.10 The principal risks are economic and geo-political. Economic risks stem from the possibility of macroeconomic destabilization and delays in structural reforms. However, the Government continues to adhere to its reform program and contemplates new reform measures including the privatization of agri-kombinats and further reforms of agricultural price and trade policy. The reopening of the country's southern border, and more recently the ending of the Serbian embargo, should help in stimulating trade and private sector development. The reforms supported by the FESAC, together with on-going dialogue with the IMF to extend the Stand-by Arrangement and the Bank Group on a proposed SAL should reduce tie risk of policy slippage. Geo-political risks stemming from regional conflicts and ethnic strife in the Balkan region remain an overhanging risk. 5.11 Project specific risks relate mainly to potential resistance at the operational level by various public institutions and services involved in the project to give up traditional influence and responsibilities. This would be mitigated by an intensive retraining program and seminars explaining the rationale for the changes introduced under the project. Another risk relates to the relatively large number of small contracts to be awarded under the project and the difficulty of their close supervision. Procurement training has been provided already to MAFWE staff. The Project Manager would be responsible for proper application of procedures. Finally, cost-sharing arrangements in the provision of advisory services to farmers may encounter poor receptivity due to past experience with Government. This risk would be mitigated by developing strong incentives for community participation. The proposed Mid-Term Review would provide an opportunity to review and change project design if required.

An essential part of the training would be a course in participatory rural appraisal in at least one agro- ecological zone and farming system. Four months after the course, the training specialist would conduct a one-week refresher and evaluation course. Subsequently, a retraining program would be expanded for MES staff at all levels, organized by the training coordinator. Each two-week course would be for about 10 staff. Each staff member would complete the initial two-week course, followed four weeks later by a one-week refresher and follow-up seminar. This training would include a practical field exercise followed by additional training and evaluation. An independent evaluation of the training program would be conducted in the second year of the program under a contract with terms of reference agreed with the World Bank. Agricultural Research 7. As agreed with MOS, the MAFWE would have overall responsibility for the program. The MAFWE has appointed an Agricultural Research Committee (ARC) whose responsibilities would include review and approval of research priorities and in evaluating proposals for funding from the Research Grant Fund. The MAFWE has also appointed a Senior Scientific Advisor (SSA), under the PFSP, to
 - 36 - Annex 5 Page 3 of 10 assist the PFSP Project Manager (PM) in managing and administering day to day activities of the program. The Ministry would establish the Agricultural Research Grant Fund no later than June 30, 1996. The guidelines for awarding research grants were agreed at negotiations. 8. ARC membership would come from a cross section of experienced individuals with experience with applied problems and opportunities facing farmers, as well as to provide a balance between public and with private sectors. ARC membership would include one representatives from MAFWE, Ministry of Science, the Faculty of Agriculture, the MES, private farmers (one each representing grain, livestock and horticultural producers), and a representative of agribusiness. The ARC would be chaired by the SSA. 9. The first year of the program are expected to feature seven, broad priority areas, specifically: 1) Integrated pest management (IPM), 2) Animal husbandry, 3) Farm management, 4) Water use efficiency, 5) Conservation tillage, 6) Pasture and range management, and 7) Evaluation of new horticultural varieties. As the program gains experience, the ARC will consider changing economic circumstances, in particular agricultural trade opportunities, experience with previous adaptive research, and the findings of the MES diagnostic surveys to modify priority areas as appropriate. 10. The research envisioned to be carried out under the adaptive research program would be on applied, practical problems facing farmers and agribusiness. (The program is not intended to fund basic, strategic research, which is the responsibility of the Ministry of Science.) Adaptive research typical of projects that could be funded might include the identification of more economic and appropriate level of herbicides; modification to livestock housing to reduce infectious diseases; identification of new fruit/vegetable varieties that would fit niche, export markets; new tillage practices and/or tillage equipment that would evaluate alternative high residue tillage techniques; and farm level cost of production studies, for example. Animal Health Program 11. The veterinary service privatization program would be managed by the Veterinary Management Unit in close collaboration with the Veterinary Chamber. The Veterinary Development Fund would be used to encourage public sector veterinarians to privatize. Under the matching grant program, Government would meet 50% of the costs associated with establishing a private veterinary practice. Any veterinarian willing to leave government service and able to fund 50% of his/her costs of establishing a private practice would be eligible. A limit of US$15,000 per veterinary station' would be established. Support would be restricted under the matching grant scheme to equipment directly related to income generating activities such as for disease diagnosis, pregnancy testing, artificial insemination, and laboratory sample analysis. At negotiations agreement has been reached on the establishment and maintenance of the Veterinary Privatization Fund by June 30, 1996, with guidelines satisfactory to the World Bank, for participation by veterinarians. 12. Private veterinarian in-service training would be provided under a project financed program designed to provide additional technical, business, and management skills necessary for a private ' Station refers to clinic or surgery.
 -37 - Annex 5 Page 4 of 10 veterinary practice. Up to two private veterinarians per veterinary station would have access to an introductory course in computers, business practices and re related office and data management software use. The project would also contract for the provision of short courses for private veterinarians on technical subjects including whole herd health and production management, ruminant and non-ruminant nutrition, management-related diseases and internal parasites. The Veterinary Chamber would be responsible for the selection of courses. 13. The Epidemiological Unit of the Veterinary Management Unit would implement the epidemiology program. It would contract with the Veterinary Institute for sample analysis, private veterinary stations for sample collection, herd health monitoring and vaccination campaigns. Work plans would be developed by the Epidemiological Unit on regional bases in collaboration with MES services. The Epidemiological Unit would manage programs, analyze and report results, and, in collaboration with MAFWE, develop associated policy and cost-effective disease control strategies. Market Information 14. The Agriculture Department of SOM would manage the development of the market information service. A MOU between the MAFWE and SOM has been signed to formalize implementation responsibilities. Rural Financial Services 15. The Project Manager would supervise the overall implementation of this component. Together with the international farm credit specialist, six farm credit specialists for a two-year term would be posted to the six strengthened opstina extension offices. The Project Manager with the help of Management Consulting firm would also supervise special studies. The international farm credit specialist would assist MAFWE's legal staff in reviewing pending legislation. Concerning implementation of the SA component, the Government, subsequent to a review of the SA initiative, would present to the World Bank for review and approval a plan for supporting strengthening and expansion of SAs before any disbursements are made on this component.

doc.abstracts: The Private Farmer Support Project will support the economic transformation process by strengthening the provision of technology and information related services to private farmers, thereby improving their production and income. The project will change mechanisms for provision of technical services to private farmers and initiate important changes in the public institutions providing such services. It will be implemented over three and a half years. Project funds will be used for technical specialists, training, equipment, vehicles, and small support grants. The project will include the following main components: 1) pilot initiatives to develop cost-sharing arrangements with farmer associations, to decentralize extension management and responsibility for support to farmers, and to strengthen Macedonian Extension Service's extension capacity; 2) support for applied agricultural research through competitively-awarded contracts; 3) support for privatization of veterinary services and development of public epidemiological and quarantine services; 4) development of a market news/information service and planning work for a private horticulture wholesale market; 5) assistance to improve farmers' access to commercial credit and to evaluate the feasibility of an apex organization for rural, member-owned Savings Associations; and 6) assistance to selected commercial banks to improve their capacity to facilitate expansion of financial services.
